随着死亡人数上升以及医院附近和周围的战斗加剧，以色列面临着越来越大的国际压力，包括来自其主要盟友美国的压力，要求其采取更多措施保护加沙的巴勒斯坦平民。

据加沙卫生官员称，过去五周，以色列军队对哈马斯武装分子发动战争，导致巴勒斯坦人在过去五周对沿海飞地的轰炸中丧生，而哈马斯武装分子于 10 月 7 日在以色列南部发动了致命的袭击。

美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯在周五访问印度时对记者表示，迄今为止，他对交火中平民的困境发表了最强烈的评论：“太多的巴勒斯坦人被杀；太多的人在过去遭受苦难。”几周。”

但布林肯重申美国支持以色列确保加沙不再被用作“发动恐怖主义的平台”的行动。

法国总统马克龙在周五晚间发表的英国广播公司采访中表示，以色列必须停止轰炸加沙和杀害平民。他说，法国“明确谴责”哈马斯的“恐怖主义”行为，但在承认以色列保护自己的权利的同时，“我们确实敦促他们停止”在加沙的轰炸。

作为回应，以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡表示，世界领导人应该谴责哈马斯，而不是以色列。内塔尼亚胡说：“哈马斯今天在加沙犯下的这些罪行明天将在巴黎、纽约和世界任何地方犯下。”

以色列表示，哈马斯武装分子在上个月的袭击中扣押了多达 240 名不同国籍的人质，如果停火，他们将利用停火协议重新集结。

沙特外交部表示，沙特阿拉伯将于周六在利雅得举办特别伊斯兰-阿拉伯联合峰会。声明称，此次联席会议“将针对巴勒斯坦加沙地带发生的特殊情况举行，各国认为有必要共同努力并提出统一的集体立场”。

人满为患的医院遭到爆炸和枪击

周六，加沙城人满为患的医院附近的战斗愈演愈烈，巴勒斯坦官员称，医院遭到爆炸和枪击。

“以色列现在正在对加沙城的医院发动战争，”希法医院院长穆罕默德·阿布·塞尔梅亚说。

他后来说，以色列对加沙市 Al-Buraq 学校的袭击造成至少 25 人死亡，房屋被毁的人们正在该学校避难。

加沙官员表示，周五凌晨，导弹落在该飞地最大的医院 Al Shifa 的院子里，损坏了印度尼西亚医院，据报道还烧毁了 Nasser Rantissi 儿科癌症医院。

以色列军方后来表示，巴勒斯坦武装分子在加沙发射的一枚失火的炮弹击中了希法。

这些医院挤满了流离失所者以及病人和医务人员，这些医院位于加沙北部，以色列称那里是哈马斯武装分子的集中地。

以色列政府发言人艾隆·利维表示，哈马斯总部位于希法医院的地下室，这意味着该设施可能会失去受保护状态并成为合法目标。

以色列称哈马斯在医院地下隧道中藏匿武器，哈马斯否认这一指控。

世界卫生组织总干事谭德塞表示，该组织在希法接触的卫生工作者被迫离开医院寻求安全。

谭德塞在社交媒体上写道：“由于安全风险，在医院避难的数千人中，许多人被迫撤离，但许多人仍然留在那里。”

“没有人是安全的”

加沙卫生部发言人阿什拉夫·齐德拉(Ashraf Al-Qidra)表示，以色列对希法医院大楼进行了五次轰炸。

“在清晨的袭击中，一名巴勒斯坦人被杀，多人受伤，”他在电话中说。路透社证实的视频显示了恐慌的场景，人们浑身是血。

医务人员早些时候表示，以色列坦克已占领纳赛尔·兰蒂西医院和圣城医院周围的阵地。

巴勒斯坦红十字会表示，以色列军队向圣城医院开枪，并发生暴力冲突，造成1人死亡、28人受伤，其中大多数是儿童。

以色列陆军发言人理查德·赫克特中校在新闻发布会上表示，军队“不会向医院开火。如果我们看到哈马斯恐怖分子从医院开枪，我们将采取我们需要做的事情。我们意识到（医院）的敏感性，但同样，如果我们看到哈马斯恐怖分子，我们就会杀死他们。”

以色列驻联合国大使吉拉德·埃尔丹表示，以色列已成立一个特别工作组，在加沙南部建立医院。 10 月 12 日，以色列在地面入侵之前命令加沙约 110 万人向南迁移。

巴勒斯坦官员周五表示，自10月7日以来，已有11,078名加沙居民在空袭和炮击中丧生。

以色列外交部表示，在 10 月 7 日的哈马斯袭击中，约有 1,200 人死亡，其中大部分是平民，这是对早先死亡人数的修订，但它补充说，一旦所有尸体的身份都得到确认，这一数字可能会再次发生变化。

以色列还表示，自 10 月 7 日以来，已有 39 名士兵在战斗中丧生。

美国财长耶伦周五表示，她同意中国国务院副总理何立峰就经济问题“加强沟通”，但警告他要打击为俄罗斯乌克兰战争提供物质支持的中国公司。

耶伦在旧金山举行两天会议后在新闻发布会上表示，两人就从美国出口管制到可能的合作领域（包括气候变化和低收入国家债务减免）等问题“进行了坦诚、直接和富有成效的讨论”。

两人在11 月 15 日至 17 日在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织 (APEC)领导人会议之前举行了会谈，美国总统乔·拜登和中国国家主席习近平计划在此次会议上举行会晤。

耶伦表示，她接受了贺建奎的邀请，作为经济领导人之间“定期接触”的一部分，贺建奎明年将返回中国。贺建奎被中国官方媒体称为一个强大的共产党经济机构的负责人。

她强调，美国无意将经济与中国脱钩，而是希望为美国企业和工人提供公平的竞争环境。

耶伦表示：“在我们的讨论中，我们一致认为深入和坦诚的讨论很重要，特别是当我们存在分歧时。” “我强调，当前不确定的全球形势使得我们保持未来有弹性的沟通渠道变得尤为重要。”

俄罗斯战争援助

耶伦表示，财政部已经看到证据表明，尽管受到西方制裁，中国公司和银行可能仍在为俄罗斯在乌克兰战争中使用的设备流动提供援助，并警告贺称，如果这样做，这些公司“将面临严重后果” 。

耶伦表示：“我们希望看到中国对此进行打击，特别是当我们能够提供信息时。”她没有透露所涉及公司的名称或贺建奎的反应的更多细节。

中国驻华盛顿大使馆发言人表示，中方预计稍后将公布此次会议的情况。

美国财政部在一份声明中表示，官员们还讨论了以色列与哈马斯的战争，耶伦谈到了“防止中东冲突升级和扩大”的必要性。

关于美国国债市场，耶伦表示，中国减持美国国债以支持人民币汇率并不令人意外，但中国并未公布有关其外汇行为的信息。

她表示，针对中国最大银行中国工商银行的勒索软件攻击并未干扰美国国债市场。

一位财政部高级官员周五表示，中国经济领导层的变化意味着财政部需要从头开始在北京建立新的联系，从耶伦7月份访问北京开始，她在那里首次会见了贺建奎。

耶伦和贺建奎周四和周五的会面没有采取任何具体行动，但双方确实就一些共同语言来描述此次接触达成了一致，这是近期美中互动中不同寻常的一步。

根据共同谈判的措辞，他们同意“努力寻求共同解决方案，尽可能解决分歧，并避免导致意外升级的误解”。

双方同意寻求“健康的经济关系，为两国企业和工人提供公平的竞争环境，造福两国人民”。

这位财政部高级官员承认，美国和中国对公平竞争环境的看法可能不同，但美方现在可以指出与此不一致的政策。

他们还承诺加强全球金融架构，包括通过最近批准的国际货币基金组织配额资金增加和计划“增加代表性不足的成员国/地区的发言权”，即中国增加股份。

预计数十万抗议者将参加周六在伦敦举行的亲巴勒斯坦游行，英国首相苏纳克批评这次集会是不尊重的，因为担心这可能会在纪念战争退伍军人的日子引发暴力。

“巴勒斯坦全国游行”是自 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击以色列以来在英国首都举行的第四次活动​​，但部长们表示应该取消这次活动，因为当天恰逢标志着世界大战结束的停战日一是纪念在军事行动中丧生的人。

警方表示，他们将有近 2,000 名警员执勤，誓言镇压因参与游行的人或反对派右翼团体和退伍军人的反抗议而造成的任何骚乱。

“我确实相信，如果这些团体聚集在一起，将会出现严重的混乱，”负责官员、副助理专员劳伦斯·泰勒说。

他告诉记者：“本周末的警务行动规模庞大，”并称这将是“具有挑战性和紧张的”。

包括英国在内的西方政府以及许多公民对哈马斯袭击表示强烈支持和同情以色列。但以色列的反应也引发了愤怒，伦敦每周都会举行抗议活动，要求停火。

巴勒斯坦团结运动的组织者表示，周六的游行将避开苏纳克唐宁街办公室附近的战争纪念碑，并将在大约两英里外的美国大使馆结束。

警方表示，他们将在与纪念活动有关的区域周围设立禁区，而自周四以来，和平纪念碑上前所未有的 24 小时警察警卫已经到位。

PCS 主任本·贾马尔 (Ben Jamal) 对路透社表示：“我们可能会举行英国政治史上最大规模的游行之一，但我可以自信地说，将有数十万人参加。”

“政客们只能在这么长时间内忽视重要的公众舆论。”

“仇恨游行者”

虽然之前的 PSC 游行总体上是和平的，但已有 100 多人因犯罪行为被捕，包括支持哈马斯（哈马斯在英国被列为恐怖组织），或举着带有攻击性口号的标语牌。

周五，三名妇女出庭，被控因佩戴滑翔伞图像支持哈马斯而犯有恐怖主义罪，警方表示，集会中分裂团体的行为变得更加暴力。

负责治安事务的内政大臣苏埃拉· 布拉弗曼(Suella Braverman)因称抗议者为“仇恨游行者”而引发争议，苏纳克在指责警方在对待“警察的方式上采取双重标准”后，面临着来自本国立法者的压力，要求解雇她。亲巴勒斯坦暴徒”。

首相本人表示，周六的抗议活动是不尊重的，但应该允许继续进行，尽管他表示将要求伦敦警察局长负责维护纪念活动。

立法者担心极右团体会利用这一场合作为暴力行为的借口。

英国保卫联盟前联合领导人史蒂芬·亚克斯利·列侬（Stephen Yaxley-Lennon）呼吁他的支持者在首都举行集会，该联盟经常举行针对伊斯兰教的暴力示威活动。

汤米·罗宾逊 (Tommy Robinson) 的亚克斯利·列侬 (Yaxley-Lennon) 在社交媒体视频中表示：“我们想向世界表明，英国人民并没有这么做。” “所以……我希望这个星期六我能在伦敦见到尽可能多的人。”

DAC泰勒表示，警方希望避免麻烦，但可能会发生冲突。

他说：“这个周末有时你会看到零星的对抗，尽管我已经采取了一切措施来应对这种情况。”

“我希望我们不会这样做，但我认为你很可能会看到警察不得不使用武力来处理我们必须处理的一些情况。”

白宫表示，美国总统乔·拜登将于周三与中国国家主席习近平一年来首次面对面会面，这是旨在遏制世界两个超级大国之间紧张关系的高风险外交。

在旧金山湾区举行的亚太经济合作组织（APEC）峰会期间，这场受到密切关注的互动可能会持续几个小时，并有来自北京和华盛顿的官员团队参与。

预计将涵盖从以色列与哈马斯战争到俄罗斯入侵乌克兰、朝鲜与俄罗斯的关系、台湾、印太、人权、芬太尼、人工智能以及“公平”贸易和经济关系等全球问题。拜登政府高级官员表示。

一位不愿透露姓名的美国官员在向记者通报情况时表示，“没有什么会被阻止；一切都摆在桌面上”。

“我们对此很清楚。我们知道几十年来塑造或改革中国的努力都失败了。但我们预计中国将在我们的有生之年继续存在并成为世界舞台上的主要参与者。”

美国官员一年多来一直在推动这次会议，他们认为北京一直在积极努力破坏美国的全球政策。

白宫在周五的一份声明中确认了会议的日期。中国外交部周五表示，习近平将于11月14日至17日访问美国，出席亚太经合组织峰会并会见拜登。

拜登和习近平将自 2022 年 11 月以来首次跨越意识形态差异发表讲话。2 月份，拜登下令击落飞越美国上空的疑似中国间谍气球后，美国总统团队发起了一场外交闪电战，以修复敌对关系。

预计主要结果将是加强外交——承诺就关键问题进行更多对话，包括气候、全球健康、经济稳定、禁毒工作，以及可能在高层冻结后恢复一些军事渠道。

另两位了解讨论情况的人士表示，双方可能会做出温和的善意姿态，以缓和谈判。

但取得深入进展将是困难的。美国和中国官员表示，两国越来越认为自己陷入了直接竞争，以确保军事优势、垄断21世纪经济并赢得二流国家的青睐。

在这座躁动不安的北加州城市，精心策划习近平访问的努力可能会被颠覆，这座城市有着悠久的左翼抗议和煽动历史。

拜登和习近平已经相识十多年，自拜登 2021 年就职以来，双方进行了六次互动，进行了数小时的交谈。但分析人士称，两人来到谈判桌前时都互相猜疑、不满，并对对方的追求抱有错误的印象。

除其他敏感话题外，预计拜登将提出中国在外国选举中的“影响力行动”，以及华盛顿认为在中国被错误拘留的美国公民的地位。

80 岁的拜登领导的经济在 COVID-19 大流行后的表现超出了预期，也超出了大多数富裕国家的表现。由于对美国民主稳定性的担忧，他不受国内选民的欢迎，正在寻求连任。

Reuters said it acquired photographs from two Gaza-based freelance photographers who were at the border on the morning of Oct. 7 and with whom it did not have a prior relationship.

HonestReporting also distanced itself from Israeli government accusations that were sparked by its article.

"There are those who took our story and pretended that they knew the answers - the Israeli government, cabinet ministers, various Twitter personalities - we didn't claim to know," Hoffman said.

Reacting to the HonestReporting article posted on X, the Israeli Foreign Ministry had described the use of the various images by the four news groups as "a serious violation of journalistic ethics."

'SHOCKED'

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office wrote on X: "These journalists were accomplices in crimes against humanity; their actions were contrary to professional ethics."

Danny Danon, a member of Netanyahu's Likud party and a former Israeli envoy to the United Nations, wrote on X after the release of the HonestReporting article that the Palestinian photojournalists should be eliminated.

"We will hunt them down together with the terrorists," he wrote.

Hoffman said he had been "shocked" to read Danon's comments. He also said: "There are clearly things in the prime minister's office statement that are not based on fact. We did not say anything firmly."

Danon and Israel's government did not immediately respond to Reuters' requests for comment in response to Hoffman's remarks.

"We are deeply concerned about the irresponsibility of HonestReporting in publishing such damaging accusations. Its executive director has accepted that there is no evidence to support the incendiary insinuations in the report," Reuters said in a statement.

"The baseless speculation in HonestReporting's post, presented as 'raising ethical questions,' has posed grave risks to journalists in the region, including those working for Reuters," the news agency added.

The AP , CNN and The New York Times referred back to their previously published statements, which included denials that they had any prior knowledge of the Oct. 7 attack.

'IDEOLOGICAL PREJUDICE'

Hoffman, who was a veteran reporter with the Jerusalem Post newspaper before joining HonestReporting, defended his group's decision to post its article without first seeking comment from any of the news organisations it had named.

He said that after the article was posted he had asked his team why they had not sought comment before publication.

"They said 'well we do not claim to be a news organisation'," he said. "With media monitoring it's more effective (to ask for a response) afterwards, in general."

HonestReporting describes itself on its website as "a charitable organisation" with a mission "to combat ideological prejudice in journalism and the media, as it impacts Israel."

Hoffman said he thought international media coverage of the ongoing war against Hamas was no longer giving prominence to the Oct. 7 events, when Hamas killed around 1,200 people and kidnapped a further 244, according to an Israeli tally.

Israel's counteroffensive in Gaza since then has killed more than 11,000 people, according to Palestinian figures.

"(Our) article for two days now has returned the international public discourse to Oct. 7. That alone is a very important accomplishment," he said.

Despite HonestReporting's suggestions that the Palestinian photojournalists had secured their images in coordination with Hamas, he said he was "happy" their pictures had been published. "Absolutely I want the world to know what happened on Oct. 7," he said.

After speaking to Reuters, HonestReporting issued a statement saying: "We unequivocally condemn calls for violence or death threats aimed at bona fide media workers."

A researcher for Microsoft-owned (MSFT.O) LinkedIn said Black Cube, based in Israel, created a network of fake personas that used bogus job postings to connect with their targets on the platform.

"Subsequently, video conversations occurred with some of the targets off-platform and clips from those conversations were used as part of a campaign to discredit NGOs (non-governmental organizations) in Hungary," the researcher, Mona Damian, said at the Cyberwarcon conference in Arlington, Virginia.

Damian said a network of fake Black Cube-run LinkedIn accounts had been taken down and that Black Cube's LinkedIn company page had also been removed "given the high volume of abuse and clear violation of our terms of service."

Black Cube did not immediately respond to messages seeking comment. The company, which once performed undercover work for Hollywood rapist Harvey Weinstein, has previously said, speaking generally, that it "does not operate in the cyber world" and that its actions were "fully compliant with local laws."

A European Union plan to spend up to 20 billion euros ($21.4 billion) on military aid for Ukraine is meeting resistance from EU countries and may not survive in its current form, diplomats say.

Josep Borrell, the EU's foreign policy chief, proposed in July that the bloc create a fund with up to 5 billion euros a year over four years as part of broader Western security commitments to bolster Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion.

But as EU defence ministers prepare to discuss the plan in Brussels on Tuesday, diplomats say multiple countries - including EU heavyweight Germany - have voiced reservations about committing such large sums years in advance.

The EU and its members have been among the biggest donors of military aid to Ukraine since Russia launched its invasion in February 2022, providing arms and equipment worth some 25 billion euros, according to the bloc's diplomatic service.

Borrell's proposal was an effort to put support on a longer-term footing, by creating a cash pot for Ukraine aid inside a bigger fund, the European Peace Facility, used to reimburse EU members for military assistance to other countries.

"I'm not going to declare it dead at this point yet. But of course, improvements can always be made," a senior EU diplomat said on Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity.

"Germany has had a lot of questions ... and rightfully so. We're talking about a lot of money."

The debate over military aid comes as EU nations are also in discussions over a proposal to give Ukraine 50 billion euros in economic assistance.

The EU is also facing challenges over other aspects of its military aid to Ukraine.

Many officials and diplomats say the bloc will struggle to meet a target of supplying Kyiv with 1 million artillery shells and missiles by March next year.

And Hungary has for months been holding up 500 million euros in payouts from the Peace Facility to EU members for Ukraine aid over Ukraine's blacklisting a Hungarian bank, OTP.

Since the bank was removed from the blacklist, Hungary has been insisting it wants guarantees it will not return there.

SECURITY PACKAGES

EU governments have stressed that long-term EU military aid must be coordinated with security packages that individual EU countries are negotiating with Kyiv, making it hard to settle on a price tag while those talks are ongoing.

At an EU summit last month, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said the focus for now should be on such bilateral packages.

Some EU members have also argued they will struggle to make a big long-term pledge as domestic budgets are squeezed.

"For some member states, there is the reality of the public finances," said a second EU diplomat.

A third EU diplomat said the likelihood of Borrell's original proposal being adopted was declining but many countries still wanted to have a commitment at EU level.

Three diplomats suggested the EU may end up deciding to go year-by-year with its commitments, rather than signing up for a larger amount stretching over four years.

  • Rebel alliance stormed outposts, seized control of towns
  • Junta leadership, facing multiple issues, at weakest since the coup
  • Around 50,000 people displaced as shelling and airstrikes continue

A rebel alliance has overrun parts of northern Myanmar, including areas bordering China, with resistance to the military junta notching its most significant win since the 2021 coup, according to a rebel commander, diplomats and analysts.

The fiercest fighting has been near Myanmar's border with China in northern Shan state where three powerful ethnic armed groups have combined to lead an offensive that has taken multiple towns and military outposts in recent weeks.

Myanmar's military-appointed president said on Thursday the country was at risk of breaking apart due to the failure to deal with the insurgency more effectively.

Alarmed by its neighbour's deteriorating situation, China's foreign ministry said on Friday that Beijing will ensure security and stability at its border with Myanmar and urged all parties there to stop fighting immediately.

Anti-junta fighters operating with "unprecedented coordination" have overrun 100 military outposts and the junta stands to lose control of key border crossings that account for some 40% of cross-border trade and a vital tax revenue source, the United States Institute of Peace think-tank said.

Around 50,000 people have been displaced in Shan, where artillery shelling and airstrikes are continuing, and some have crossed into China, the United Nations said on Friday.

"It is very significant," said one diplomat with knowledge of the assault named by opposition groups as "Operation 1027", after the date it started.

"This is the weakest the Tatmadaw has been since the coup," the diplomat said, referring to Myanmar's military and asking not to be named. Two other diplomats agreed with that assessment.

A junta spokesman did not respond to requests for comment.

Maung Saungkha, leader of the Bamar People's Liberation Army, which contributed troops to the offensive, told Reuters the rebel alliance had spent more than a year preparing to take on the better-armed military.

The operation was "the biggest and most successful of the Spring Revolution", he said, referring to the popular uprising against the junta that ousted a democratically elected government led by Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi in February 2021.

Resistance groups are working closely to batter the already stretched military, said an adviser to Myanmar's parallel civilian administration, known as the National Unity Government, which has backed separate assaults on towns in Sagaing division.

"This opportunity will never ever come back," said the adviser, who declined to be named.

CHINA'S SHADOW

So far, rebel troops have faced unexpectedly weak opposition from the military, according to analysts and resistance leaders who spoke to local media.

The offensive puts further pressure on a military leadership already facing biting economic sanctions, a foreign exchange shortage and a corruption crisis that has ensnared several of junta leader Min Aung Hlaing's allies, the diplomats said.

Myanmar's relationship with China has also been strained over border issues and the latest offensive, led by the "Brotherhood Alliance" comprising the Arakan Army, Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army and the Ta'ang National Liberation Army, could not have been carried out if Beijing had opposed it, the diplomats said.

Beijing has in recent months been putting pressure on Myanmar to crack down on criminal syndicates running massive telecoms and other online scams from the border areas.

In a statement announcing the operation, the alliance said they intended to remove those enclaves, which they said were protected by the junta.

But China, which seeks to protect major economic investments in the area, has also called for a ceasefire and confirmed this week that there had been Chinese casualties because of firing from the Myanmar fighting spilling over.

While the junta has been weakened, the diplomats said the possibility of an imminent collapse of the armed forces was remote, though they could lose more territory.

"If the regime is able to mount a decisive response, it will likely be able to reopen the trade routes to China," said Richard Horsey, senior Myanmar adviser at International Crisis Group.

"If not, this will be seen as a sign of historic weakness."
